Description: A mould-made tear-shaped oil-lamp with double-convex body with a sharp carination. Long, flat-topped nozzle with a rounded end, and lines incised on the neck. Small depressed disc which is separated from the shoulder by a groove. Red clay. No painted decoration.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Parallels from Naukratis (Bristol Museum H844; Ashmolean GR.213.1899; GR.214.1899; Bolton Museum 1886.31.8; Nottingham NCM 1888-45; Boston MFA RES.86.131), including a mould (Nottingham, Castle Museum NCM 1888-56). Egyptian parallel from Buto, in the British Museum, has been dated to the 1st century BC (Bailey 1988, Q2093).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.042) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4833 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
